_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this Risk Management Plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia, arsine, boron trichloride, chlorine, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride, hydrogen fluoride, hydrogen selenide, hydrogen sulfide, phosphine, and sulfur dioxide.  

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. maintains a safety and environmental program, which is administered by the Director of Operations with assistance from Corporate Risk Management.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling of highly hazardous chemicals.  For example, written procedures have been developed for operating and maintaining the covered processes.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.  The facility's maintenance program requires periodic inspections of process and safety equipment to ensure they are in good operating condition.  The overall safety and environmental program is geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, the program incorporates emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, trained personnel will assess the situation and notify the emergency response team and outside responding agencies as necessary.    

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. manufactures industrial grade gases and trans-fills into compressed gas cylinders of varying sizes.  The business is located at 1700 Scepter Road in Waverly, Tennessee.  The regulated substances maintained at the facility are ammonia, arsine, boron trichloride, chlorine, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride, hydrogen fluoride, hydrogen selenide, hydrogen sulfide, phosphi

he environment.  Most cylinders are equipped with a fusible relief plug which protects the equipment from overpressurization and rupture.  Detectors are installed near the chlorine purification process to warn personnel of a leak, and any released chlorine vapor is exhausted to the scrubber system.  Regular inspections and tests are performed to ensure these controls are in good working order.
 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The ERP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) handling chemical releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and in-house emergency response personnel and 4) administering first aid measures for chemical exposure.  Employees perform drills and receive refresher training on the ERP.  In the event of a chemical release, trained emergency response personnel will assess the situation and contact the fire department as necessary for assistance.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:

¿	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
¿	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a))."

There have been no significant releases of regulated substances from covered processes over the past five years (June 2009 - June 2014) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantities for each of the chemicals.  In addition, there have been no releases of regulated substances that meet the RMP definition of "accident" as described above.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Process Hazard An

alyses and Compliance Audits have been performed on the regulated processes, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
